A '''fleeting expletive''' is a [[non-scripted]] verbal [[profanity]] or [[obscenity]] expressed and broadcast during a [[live television|live]] television broadcast or radio broadcast. The term appears primarily in discussions of United States [[broadcasting]] law.
==Notable examples==
In chronological order: *While accepting her Lifetime Achievement Award at the 2002 [[Billboard Music Awards]], [[Cher]] said "fuck 'em" regarding those she felt had criticized her throughout her career.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cherworld.com/cher-news/cher-nailed-for-f-word-indecency/ |title=Cher nailed for F-word indecency » Cherworld.com - Cher Photos, Music, Tour & Tickets |publisher=Cherworld.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-08}}</ref> *During the January 2003 [[Golden Globe Awards]], [[Bono]] accepted an award exclaiming, "This is really, really, [[fuck]]ing brilliant." *At the December 2003 Billboard Music Awards, [[Nicole Richie]] said, "Have you ever tried to get [[cowshit]] out of a [[Prada]] purse? It's not so [[fuck]]ing simple." * On an episode of ''[[Big Brother 10 (U.S.)|Big Brother 10]]'' (2008), there was a heated argument with lots of muted expletives; however, one went through when someone said, "Memphis was in the fucking room." * [[Jenny Slate]] said "and I fucking love you for that" during a parody of a talk show by biker women. It was her first appearance as a player on ''[[Saturday Night Live]]''.<ref>{{cite news |first= Dave|last= Itzkoff|authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Newcomer Makes a Slip |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/09/28/arts/television/28arts-SNLNEWCOMERM_BRF.html |quote=The utterance came in a sketch, which began about 12:42 a.m. on Sunday, in which Ms. Slate played the hard-living host of 'Biker Chick Chat' who interviews similarly tough-talking women. |work=[[New York Times]] |date=September 27, 2009 |accessdate=2009-09-28 }}</ref> *On March 23, 2010, U.S. Vice President [[Joe Biden]], commenting on the passage of the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act]] during a live press conference, said to U.S. President [[Barack Obama]], "This is a big fucking deal." The comment was picked up by [[CNN]] news microphones.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ic2eEcnwghU|title=Biden Drops the F-Bomb?|publisher=[[Talking Points Memo]]|date=2010-03-23|accessdate=2010-07-13}}</ref> *On November 19, 2011, during a live taping of [[ESPN]]'s [[College GameDay (football)|College GameDay]] at the [[University of Houston]], [[college football]] analyst [[Lee Corso]] said, "Ah, fuck it" before he put on the headwear of [[Shasta (mascot)|Shasta]], the [[Houston Cougars|University of Houston Cougars]]' mascot, demonstrating his prediction that the Cougars would beat the [[SMU Mustangs|Mustangs]] of [[Southern Methodist University]].<ref>{{cite web|author=11/19/11 12:11pm 11/19/11 12:11pm |url=http://deadspin.com/5861123/ah-fuck-it-lee-corso-strikes-again |title='"Ah Fuck It": Lee Corso Strikes Again', Deadspin |publisher=Deadspin.com |date= |accessdate=2013-10-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.chron.com/sportsmedia/2011/11/corso-picks-cougars-with-an-f-bomb-to-boot/ |title="Corso picks Cougars with F-Bomb, then Apologizes", ''Houston Chronicle'' blog |publisher=Blog.chron.com |date=2011-11-19 |accessdate=2013-10-08}}</ref> Corso's co-hosts [[Kirk Herbstreit]] and [[Chris Fowler]] and their guest speaker [[Carl Lewis]] laughed hysterically in response to his use of the expletive,<ref>[http://deadspin.com/5861123/ah-fuck-it-lee-corso-strikes-again '"Ah Fuck It": Lee Corso Strikes Again'], Deadspin</ref><ref>[http://blog.chron.com/sportsmedia/2011/11/corso-picks-cougars-with-an-f-bomb-to-boot "Corso picks Cougars with F-Bomb, then Apologizes"] Image capturing co-hosts' reaction, ''Houston Chronicle'' blog</ref> for which Corso later apologized.<ref>http://espn.go.com/video/clip?id=7254423 "Lee Corso Apologizes", ESPN Video</ref> *On December 18, 2011, during a [[CBS]] broadcast of the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] at the [[St. Louis Rams]], St. Louis guard Harvey Dahl protested referee [[Jerome Boger]]'s holding call against him by saying, "I know you didn't just call me for holding. That's not fuckin' holding!" It was heard over the stadium PA system through Boger's open microphone, and aired. CBS commentator [[Dan Dierdorf]] apologized for the slip, and Dahl was assessed a second penalty for unsportsmanlike conduct.<ref>https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2Eu_OY3Lh3M</ref> *On November 4, 2012, during the [[Miami Dolphins|Dolphins]]-[[Indianapolis Colts|Colts]] game at [[Lucas Oil Stadium]] in [[Indianapolis]], referee [[Tony Corrente]] loudly said, "God damn it!" [[CBS]] play-by-play announcer [[Kevin Harlan]] apologized on-air because Corrente's illegal language slipped past the censors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000090054/article/pottymouth-ref-gives-dolphinscolts-crowd-an-earful|title=Potty-mouth ref gives Dolphins-Colts crowd an earful|work=[[National Football League]]|date=2012-11-04|accessdate=2012-11-04}}</ref> Corrente himself would apologize, but not before the [[National Football League]] fined him a game check.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nfl.com/news/story/0ap1000000095934/article/nfl-fines-referee-for-swearing-on-open-mic|title=NFL fines referee for swearing on open mic|work=[[National Football League]]|date=2012-11-16|accessdate=2012-11-16}}</ref> *On April 20, 2013, during a passionate pre-game speech dedicated to the victims of the [[Boston Marathon bombing]], [[Boston Red Sox]] player [[David Ortiz]] said, "This is our fucking city."<ref>http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/04/20/red-sox-ceremony-david-ortiz-boston_n_3123316.html</ref> [[FCC]] chairman [[Julius Genachowski]] later tweeted from the official page of the organization, saying "David Ortiz spoke from the heart at today's Red Sox game. I stand with Big Papi and the people of Boston."<ref>https://twitter.com/FCC/status/325714412143013888?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw</ref> Although 25 complaints were lodged with the FCC, no action was taken and neither Ortiz nor the Boston Red Sox were fined for using the expletive.<ref>http://www.thewire.com/entertainment/2013/07/there-were-25-fcc-complaints-over-big-papis-boston-rallying-cuss/66852/</ref> *On October 28, 2017, during Game 4 of the [[2017 World Series]] matchup between the [[Houston Astros]] and the [[Los Angeles Dodgers]] at [[Minute Maid Park]] in [[Houston]], Astros player [[Brian McCann (baseball)|Brian McCann]] used "Fuck" after being struck-out by Dodgers pitcher [[Alex Wood (baseball)|Alex Wood]]. The word was picked up on a [[FOX]] camera.{{citation needed|date=October 2017}}
==U.S. Supreme Court case== {{main|Federal Communications Commission v. Fox Television Stations (2009)}} On March 17, 2008, the [[United States Supreme Court]] agreed to [[court hearing|hear]], in September 2008, a case on whether the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC) is allowed to regulate the use of fleeting expletives on television broadcasts.<ref name="BBC">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/americas/7301244.stm|title=US Court to Rule on TV Expletives|publisher=BBC News|date=2008-03-17|accessdate=2008-03-20}}</ref><ref name="CNN">{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/US/03/17/fcc.expletives/|title=High Court to Review Penalties for TV Expletives|publisher=CNN|last=Mears|first=Bill|date=2008-03-17|accessdate=2008-03-20}}</ref><ref name="CSM">{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2008/0318/p02s01-usju.html|title=FCC's Obscenity Rule to Get Supreme Court's Ear|work=[[Christian Science Monitor]]|last=Richey|first=Warren|date=2008-03-18|accessdate=2008-03-20}}</ref><ref name="LATimes">{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/washingtondc/la-na-scotus18mar18,1,6067658.story |title=Supreme Court to Rule on Broadcast Indecency |work=[[Los Angeles Times]] |last=Savage |first=David G. |date=2008-03-18 |accessdate=2008-03-20 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513120049/http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/washingtondc/la-na-scotus18mar18,1,6067658.story |archivedate=2008-05-13 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The parties in the case are the [[Fox Broadcasting Company]] (supported by other [[television network]]s including [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], [[CBS]], and [[NBC]]) and the FCC.<ref name="BBC"/><ref name="CNN"/><ref name="CSM"/><ref name="LATimes"/> A [[federal appeals court]] had ruled in the favor of the networks; the Supreme Court has agreed to hear the FCC's appeal.<ref name="BBC"/><ref name="CNN"/><ref name="CSM"/><ref name="LATimes"/>
In a ruling issued April 28, 2009, the United States Supreme Court ruled to uphold the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) fleeting expletive rule.<ref name="WSJ.com">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB124091903135863347|title=Court Upholds FCC 'Fleeting Expletive' Rule |work=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=2009-04-28|accessdate=2009-04-28 | first=Jess | last=Bravin}}</ref> The court reversed a lower court ruling in the 2nd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in New York which found in favor of [[Fox Television]] that the FCC had not properly followed procedures in creating the rule. In the 5-4 ruling by Justice [[Antonin Scalia]], "the court did not definitively settle the [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] implications of allowing a federal agency to [[censorship|censor]] broadcasts."<ref>[http://reason.com/archives/2010/04/05/the-fcc-doesnt-need-to-be The FCC Doesn't Need to Be] by Peter Suderman, ''[[Reason (magazine)|Reason]]''</ref> Instead the court suggested the First Amendment issue should be raised in a [[Federal Appeals Court]].
==U.S. Second Circuit Court of Appeals== In a ruling announced July 13, 2010, the [[U.S. Second Circuit Court of Appeals]] struck down the FCC indecency policy on fleeting expletives. Calling it "unconstitutionally vague", the unanimous three judge panel found the policy could infringe upon the constitutionally protected [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] [[freedom of speech]]. According to the panel, the policy "created a chilling effect that goes far beyond the fleeting expletives at issue here", in part due to a lack of guidance on what content is considered offensive.<ref>[http://money.cnn.com/2010/07/13/news/economy/fcc_indecency/?iref=NS1 FCC Indecency Rules Struck Down] by Julianne Pepitone, ''[[CNN Money]]''</ref>
Fox released a statement stating, "We have always felt that the government's position on fleeting expletives was unconstitutional," and, "While we will continue to strive to eliminate expletives from live broadcasts, the inherent challenges broadcasters face with live television, coupled with the human element required for monitoring, must allow for the unfortunate isolated instances where inappropriate language slips through."<ref name="nytimes.com">[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/07/14/business/media/14indecent.html?src=busln F.C.C. Indecency Policy Rejected on Appeal] by Edward Wyatt, ''[[New York Times]]''</ref>
FCC Chairman [[Julius Genachowski]] indicated the commission will be "reviewing the court's decision in light of our commitment to protect children, empower parents, and uphold the First Amendment."<ref name="nytimes.com"/>
==U.S. Supreme Court ruling== In June 2012, the Supreme Court rescinded several fines issued by the FCC regarding indecent content, including the Fox case stemming from the 2002 ''Billboard'' Music Awards. The court ruled that the FCC's change in enforcement policy to target fleeting instances of profanities and nudity on television was too vague, thus violating their rights to [[Due Process Clause|due process]]. The court did not address the policies themselves.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/22/business/media/justices-reject-indecency-fines-on-narrow-grounds.html|title=Supreme Court Rejects F.C.C. Fines for Indecency|last=Liptak|first=Adam|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-10-02|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2012/06/supreme-court-cops-out-again-on-fleeting-expletives/|title=Supreme Court cops out, again, on "fleeting expletives"|work=Ars Technica|access-date=2018-10-02|language=en-us}}</ref>

'''"Hail Satan"''', sometimes expressed in a [[Latinisation (literature)|Latinized]] version as ''Ave Satanas'' (or ''Ave Satana''), is an [[Utterance|expression]] used by some [[Satanism|Satanists]]<ref name="Barto 1992 86">{{cite book|title=The Secret Life of a Satanist: The Authorized Biography of Anton Lavey|last=Barton|first=Blanche|authorlink=Blanche Barton|year=1992|publisher=Feral House| pages=86|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4oKYuEQBFrUC&q=%22The+Secret+Life+of+a+Satanist%22&dq=%22The+Secret+Life+of+a+Satanist%22|isbn=978-0-922915-12-5}}</ref> to show their dedication to [[Satan]],<ref>{{cite book|title=When Children Kill|last=Ewing|first=Charles Patrick|year=1990|publisher=Lexington Books,|isbn=0-669-21883-9|pages=17|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7V9HAAAAMAAJ&q=%22hail+satan%22+initiation&dq=%22hail+satan%22+initiation}}</ref> but has also been used for the purpose of comedy or satire.<ref name="Serilla">{{cite news|first=Scott|last=Serilla|title='Run' to the 'Mr. Show' DVD|url=http://www.michigandaily.com/content/run-mr-show-dvd|work=[[Michigan Daily]]|publisher=|date=September 4, 2003|accessdate=2008-08-13}}</ref> Believers in [[backmasking]] think they can hear "Hail Satan" and other messages to Satan in some songs played in reverse, such as "[[Walk This Way]]" by [[Aerosmith]].<ref>{{cite book|title=Hip Hop Decoded|author=Black Dot|author2=Grandmaster Caz|year=2005|publisher=MOME Publishing|isbn=0-9772357-0-X|pages=17|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8LlRSo4mkhIC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Hip+Hop+Decoded}}</ref> The variation ''[[Ave Satani]]'', though grammatically incorrect, is sometimes used, likely originating from its use by [[Jerry Goldsmith]] in his theme music to ''[[The Omen]]''.
Some adherents to a traditional pagan faith (such as the musician [[Gaahl]]) have been known to use the phrase to mock Christians or Christianity, using the similarities between Satan as phallic and passionate and pagan fertility-gods such as [[Freyr]] in this rhetoric as a disambiguation.{{clarify|date=April 2014}}{{citation needed|date=April 2014}}
== Cultural history == The phrase "Hail Satan" is documented as early as 1808, where it is said in the poem ''The Monk of Cambray'' by an evil [[monk]] who uses his pact with Satan to advance in the ranks of the [[Catholic Church]] (and finally become Pope).<ref>{{cite book|last=Colman|first=George|title=Eccentric Tales: In Verse|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NWc1AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA19|year=1812|publisher=T. Tegg and W. Allason|page=19url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NWc1AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA19|quote= "''Hail, Satan!'' cried he, the Pope I'll be, on my bond I demand thy compliance!"}}</ref>
The Latin version ''Ave Satanas'' (in its variant spelling ''Ave Sathanas''), often appears in literature at least from the 1800s, notably in the popular 1895 [[faust]]ian novel ''[[The Sorrows of Satan]]'',<ref>{{cite book|title=The Sorrows of Satan|author=[[Marie Corelli|Corelli, Marie]]|year=1895|pages=443|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZFjQAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA443|publisher=J.B. Lippincott company|isbn=0-19-283324-3|quote= "—the waves seemed to roar ''Ave Sathanas''! —the wind shrieked it to the thunder,—the lightning wrote it in a snaky line of fire on the darkness, ''Ave Sathanas''!"}}</ref> and earlier in an 1862 play ''[[St Clement's Day|St. Clement's Eve]]''<ref>{{cite book|title=St. Clement's Eve|author=[[Henry Taylor (dramatist)|Taylor, Henry]]|year=1862|pages=16|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s80OAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA16|publisher=Chapman and Hall|quote= "...he was seen at midnight in the Rue des Ursulins hanging and whirling round and round the gibbet, whiles the dead bodies, swinging in the wind, sang ''Ave Sathanas!''"}}</ref> (in reference to satanic undertakings supposed to take place at midnight in a district of Paris). After the phrase "Hail Satan" appeared in the [[1967 in literature|1967]] book ''[[Rosemary's Baby (novel)|Rosemary's Baby]]'' by [[Ira Levin]] and the 1968 [[Rosemary's Baby (film)|film adaptation]] of it, where it is said by Satanists when they believe Satan's will has been accomplished, and had also appeared in other films and in stock footage, the phrase became part of the common conception of what Satanists say.<ref name="Gunn 2005 93–120">{{cite journal |last=Gunn |first=Joshua |year=2005 |title=Prime-time Satanism: rumor-panic and the work of iconic topoi |journal=Visual Communication |volume=4 |issue=1 |pages=93–120 |url=http://vcj.sagepub.com/cgi/content/abstract/4/1/93 |accessdate=2008-08-16 |doi=10.1177/1470357205048939}}</ref> Some film actors were reluctant to say it, and of those who did some felt they experienced negative life events afterwards, such as divorce.<ref>{{cite news|first=Susan|last=Dominus|authorlink=|title=A woman possessed|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/fashion/main.jhtml?xml=/fashion/2006/06/04/stjulia04.xml&page=1|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|publisher=|date=April 6, 2007|accessdate=2008-08-13 | location=London}}</ref>
Coinciding with its appearance in ''Rosemary's Baby'', the phrase became a common greeting and ritual term in the [[Church of Satan]] (founded in 1966), both in its English form, ''Hail Satan'', as well as in the Latin version of it, ''Ave Satanas''. When ''Ave Satanas'' was used, it was often preceded by the term ''Rege Satanas'' ("Reign, Satan"). (''Rege Satanas'' can be heard in the video of a widely publicized Church of Satan wedding performed by LaVey on February 1, 1967.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-pwAOSwHuTQ Video of 1967 Church of Satan wedding.]</ref>) The combination "''Rege Satanas, Ave Satanas, Hail Satan!''" is found as a greeting in early Church of Satan correspondence,<ref>Published in {{cite book |last=Aquino |first=Michael |title=The Church of Satan |year=2002}}.</ref> as well as in their 1968 recording ''The Satanic Mass'',<ref>LaVey, Anton, ''The Satanic Mass'', LP (Murgenstrumm Records, 1968)</ref> and ultimately in their 1969 book ''[[The Satanic Bible]]''.<ref>{{cite book|title=The Satanic Bible|last=LaVey|first=Anton|authorlink=Anton LaVey|year=1969|pages=75|url=http://std.kku.ac.th/4830401674/The%20Satanic%20Bible.pdf|isbn=0-380-01539-0|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100214195009/http://std.kku.ac.th/4830401674/The%20Satanic%20Bible.pdf|archivedate=2010-02-14|df=}}</ref> The same combination also appeared in 1969 in the non-Church of Satan record album by the rock band [[Coven (band)|Coven]], in a 13 minute long "Satanic Mass" of their own.<ref>On the album, ''[[Witchcraft Destroys Minds & Reaps Souls]]'', LP (Dunwich Productions/Mercury Records, 1969)</ref> The use of "Hail Satan" by Coven (as well as their use of the [[sign of the horns]] and [[inverted cross]]es on the same album) was the first time this phrase was used in rock music. The phrase is used in some versions of the [[Black Mass]],<ref>{{cite book|title=La Messe Noire|last=Melech|first=Aubrey|year=1985|publisher=Sui Anubis|location=London|isbn=0-947762-03-5|pages=52|url=http://www.templeofbaphomet.com/library/LaMesseNoire.pdf}}</ref> where it often accompanies the phrase "[[shemhamforash]]" and is said at the end of each prayer. This rite was performed by the [[Church of Satan]]<ref name="Barto 1992 86" /> appearing in the documentary ''[[Satanis]]'' in 1969.<ref name="Gunn 2005 93–120"/> Some [[occultism|occultists]] accompany it with similar addresses to other gods or figures they revere.<ref>{{cite book|title=Gods of the Blood |last=Gardell |first=Matthias |publisher=Duke University Press|year=2003|pages=284|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FIwwWSSL5JIC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Gods+of+the+Blood|isbn=978-0-8223-3071-4}}</ref> Rituals involving the phrase tend to be more likely to be mentioned in the press at Halloween.<ref>{{cite news|first=Silke|last=Tudor |title=Night Crawler|url=http://www.sfweekly.com/1996-11-06/music/night-crawler|format=|work=[[SF Weekly]] |date=November 6, 1996|accessdate=2008-08-13}}</ref>
"[[Ave Satani]]", the theme song for ''[[The Omen]]'' (1976), written by [[Jerry Goldsmith]], which won him an [[Academy Award]],<ref>{{cite news|first=Jeff |last=Berkwits |title=The Omen/The Final Conflict: The Deluxe Editions |url=http://www.scifi.com/sfw/sound/sfw8018.html |work=[[SciFi.com#SciFi.com|SciFi.com]] |publisher= |date=January 14, 2002 |accessdate=2008-08-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090208194410/http://www.scifi.com/sfw/sound/sfw8018.html |archivedate=February 8, 2009 }}</ref> has a title which is intended to mean "Hail Satan" in Latin, in opposition to "Ave Christi". (The song contains other Latin phrases inverting Christ, such as "Ave Versus Christi", meaning "Hail Anti-Christ", and "Corpus Satani", an inversion of "Corpus Christi", the body of Christ). The song has been described as hair-raising and has inspired cover versions such as those by [[Fantômas]] or [[Gregorian (band)|Gregorian]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Paul|last=Howlett|title=Pick of the day:The Omen|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2003/may/20/tvandradio.television|work=[[guardian.co.uk]]|publisher=|date=May 20, 2003|accessdate=2008-08-13 | location=London}}</ref> The music is used in comic portrayals of stock "sinister" characters, for instance in the ''[[South Park]]'' episode "[[Woodland Critter Christmas]]", which involves devil-worshiping woodland creatures, a version of the "Ave Satani" is heard in the background when the animals use their demonic powers; also the episode's [[commercial bumper]]s involving a squirrel saying "Hail Satan!" The chant is also parodied in the episode "[[Damien (South Park)|Damien]]", where Damien is accompanied by the chant "Rectus Dominus Cheesy Poofs."
In 1985, the phrase received national news coverage in the United States when [[serial killer]] [[Richard Ramirez]], known as the "Night Stalker", shouted "Hail Satan!" as he was led from the courtroom, while raising his hand with a [[pentagram]] drawn onto it.<ref name="LosAngeles">{{cite news |first= Robert W.|last= Stewart|authorlink= |title= Ramirez Says He's Innocent--'Hail Satan!' |url= https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/64560749.html?dids=64560749:64560749&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Oct+24%2C+1985&author=ROBERT+W.+STEWART&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Ramirez+Says+He's+Innocent+-%60Hail+Satan!'&pqatl=google|work= [[Los Angeles Times]]|page= 1|department= Main News|date= October 24, 1985}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/11/08/us/court-in-los-angeles-gives-night-stalker-death-in-13-killings.html|title=Court in Los Angeles Gives 'Night Stalker' Death in 13 Killings|accessdate=2008-08-13 | work=The New York Times | date=1989-11-08}}</ref> Members of Ramirez's family denied that he said the phrase, believing that he said "We'll see,"<ref>{{cite book|last=Linedecker|first=Clifford L.|title=Night Stalker|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=92nuEgXE2rIC&pg=PA200|year=1991|publisher=St. Martin's Press|isbn=978-0-312-92505-5|page=200}}</ref> but "Hail Satan" was still being used by journalists over twenty years later as being characteristic of Ramirez.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/e/a/1996/09/22/NEWS3710.dtl&type=printable |title=Noise of the Spheres: Inspired by Videodrome, SST and Dick, NASA Space Universe Make a Cosmic Racket|accessdate=2008-08-13 | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | first=Marsha | last=Ginsburg | date=1997-04-21}}</ref> In reviewing whether Ramirez was deprived of his [[due process]] and [[right to a fair trial]] by being restrained by leg shackles, the [[Supreme Court of California]] itself highlighted Ramirez's use of "Hail Satan" to support its conclusion that the trial court did not abuse its discretion in ordering Ramirez to be physically restrained during trial.<ref>{{cite court |litigants= People v. Ramirez |vol= 39|reporter= Cal.4th |opinion= 398|pinpoint= 451|court= [[Supreme Court of California]]|date= August 7, 2006|url= http://google.com/search?q=cache:HePYwmdGHVsJ:caselaw.findlaw.com/data2/californiastatecases/S012944.DOC|quote="In court, during his arraignment in municipal court, defendant said, "Hail Satan", and displayed a pentagram and the number 666 on his palm. Under the circumstances of the present case, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in ordering defendant to be physically restrained during trial."}}</ref>
The phrase may be used ironically by heavy metal fans as part of their rebellious ethos.<ref name="Henry H. Owings 2006">{{cite book|title=Chunklet Presents the Overrated Book|author=Henry H. Owings|author2=Patton Oswalt|year=2006|publisher=Last Gasp|isbn=0-86719-657-2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-PzQX-9KBekC&pg=PT198&dq=%22hail+satan%22}}</ref> Heavy metal musicians may use it as part of their act or their songs, such as "[[Hail Satanas We Are the Black Legions]]" by [[Mütiilation]]. Heavy metal musicians, for instance [[Ozzy Osbourne]], a member of the [[Church of England]], rarely consider themseves to be Satanists, instead using it as part of their stage [[persona]], a [[role]] they play.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E0CE4D81E30F930A1575AC0A964958260 |title= AT TEA WITH: Ossy Osbourne; Family Man. Fights Fat, Is Good With Kids.|accessdate=2008-08-17 | work=The New York Times | first=Nick | last=Ravo | date=1992-09-23}}</ref> [[RuPaul's Drag Race]] Season 4 Winner [[Sharon Needles]] has a song called ''Hail Satan'', in which she cites icons from the satanic culture.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}}
The ubiquity of the phrase has led to it being used in [[parody|parodic]] imitation of [[evangelism]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ocweekly.com/music/music/aural-reports/27920/|title=Noise of the Spheres: Inspired by Videodrome, SST and Dick, NASA Space Universe Make a Cosmic Racket|accessdate=2008-08-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019212254/http://www.ocweekly.com/music/music/aural-reports/27920/|archivedate=2007-10-19|df=}}</ref> as with the [[Mr. Show with Bob and David]] sketch "Hail Satan Network" which includes chaacters who are Satanic [[televangelism|televangelists]].<ref name="Serilla"/> It received another humorous use when ''[[The Simpsons]]'' character [[Bart Simpson]] was punished for using it to end the [[Pledge of Allegiance (United States)|Pledge of Allegiance]] in the episode "[[Burns' Heir]]".<ref>{{cite news|first=Richard|last=Corliss|title=The Cartoon Character |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,988514,00.html|work=Time magazine |date=June 8, 1998|accessdate=2008-08-16}}</ref>
"Hail Satan" is frequently shouted to the heavens during successful operations and destruction of high value enemy assets by the Goonswarm Federation alliance in the popular space-based MMO, Eve Online.
== Reputation == Some of those who believe in [[backmasking]], along with some [[Christian fundamentalism|Christian fundamentalists]], believe messages such as "Hail Satan" may [[subliminal stimuli|subliminally]] inspire people to do evil,<ref>{{cite book|title=The Beast of Adam Gorightly: Collected Rantings (1992-2004)|last=Gorightly|first=Adam|year=2005|publisher=Virtualbookworm Publishing|location=|isbn=1-58939-781-9|pages=27|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fH_R_iP3yQ8C&pg=PA26&dq=%22hail+satan%22}}</ref> a view which may have received some reinforcement when the phrase was used as part of the vandalizing of churches,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wickedlocal.com/plymouth/news/x1346898655/Church-hit-with-satanic-graffiti|title=Church hit with satanic graffiti|accessdate=2008-08-13|author=Staff reports|date=August 4, 2008|publisher=wickedlocal.com}}</ref> but its use then might have been the expression of a general anti-religious sentiment, as suggested by its use along with slogans such as "Think, don't Pray".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbc10.com/news/14205738/detail.html|title=Satanic, Anti-Religious Graffiti Spray-PaintedOn Area Churches|accessdate=2008-08-13}}</ref> Vandalism accompanying it may include the [[Anarchist symbolism|anarchy symbol]] or other slogans intended to shock, such as racial slurs.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.komonews.com/news/archive/4105891.html|title=MOUNTLAKE TERRACE - "We're going to catch these guys."|accessdate=2008-08-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090211030713/http://www.komonews.com/news/archive/4105891.html|archivedate=2009-02-11|df=}}</ref> It can accompany symbols such as a [[swastika]], inverted pentagram, or inverted cross. Such vandalism is usually by rebellious young people rather than Satanists, whose activities are not often criminal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SB&p_theme=sb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB0D989F3D4C7CC&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=SATANIC ACTIVITY ON RISE BUT NOT USUALLY CRIME|accessdate=2008-08-16}}</ref>
[[Rick Alan Ross]], an [[anti-cult movement|anti-cultist]] and [[deprogramming|deprogrammer]], referred to the murder trial of [[Scott Peterson]], in which the defense made the claim that the killings were by a "Satanic cult" rather than the defendant. Ross called this a ridiculous manifestation of the [[Satanic ritual abuse|Satanic panic]], referred to it as a "Hail Satan Pass", similar to the [[Hail Mary pass]] in football,<ref>{{cite news|first=Garrett|last=Kamps|title=June 3: Cult Expert Calls Peterson Theory 'Ridiculous'|url=http://www.ktvu.com/news/2242949/detail.html|work=KTVU.com|date=June 2, 2003|accessdate=2008-08-13|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080922074357/http://www.ktvu.com/news/2242949/detail.html|archivedate=September 22, 2008|df=}}</ref> a desperate and unlikely attempt.{{citation needed|date=April 2014}}

[[Hebrew University]]}} |doctoral_advisor = [[Alfred Tarski]] |doctoral_students = Shlomo Vinner, Leo Marcus, Arnon Avron, Liu Yang }} '''Haim Gaifman''' is a logician, probability theorist, and philosopher of language. He works in [[mathematical logic]] and developed the iterated [[Ultraproduct|ultrapower]] technique in [[set theory]] and models of [[Peano arithmetic]]. Further, he has results in the foundations of probability, defining probabilities on [[First-order logic|first-order]] and on richer languages. He has also worked in [[philosophy of language]], [[philosophy of mathematics]], and [[Theoretical computer science|theoretical computer science]].[http://philosophy.columbia.edu/directories/faculty/haim-gaifman Haim Gaifman], retrieved 2018-04-06 Early in his studies, he was the research assistant of [[Rudolf Carnap]] and worked on the foundations of probability theory. In 1958 he received his M.Sc. at [[Hebrew University]]. Then in 1962, he received his Ph.D. at [[University of California, Berkeley]] under [[Alfred Tarski]] on the topic of infinite [[Boolean algebra|Boolean algebras]].{{MathGenealogy|id=32667}} Since, he has held various permanent and visiting positions in mathematics, philosophy and computer science departments. While he was professor of mathematics at the Hebrew University, he taught courses in philosophy and directed the program in History and Philosophy of Science. Gaifman currently holds the position of professor emeritus at Hebrew University and a professorship at [[Columbia University]]. His recent interests include foundations of probability, rational choice, philosophy of mathematics, logical systems that formalize aspects of natural reasoning, Frege and theories of naming. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://philpapers.org/s/Haim%20Gaifman Works by Haim Gaifman] *[https://haimgaifman.net Haim Gaifman] personal home page {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gaifman, Haim}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Columbia University faculty]] [[Category:American logicians]] [[Category:Philosophers of language]] [[Category:Set theorists]] [[Category:21st-century American philosophers]]

'''Indexed grammars''' are a generalization of [[context-free grammars]] in that [[nonterminal]]s are equipped with lists of ''flags'', or ''index symbols''. The language produced by an indexed grammar is called an '''[[indexed language]]'''.
==Definition==
===Modern definition by Hopcroft and Ullman===
<!---supplemented from talk page # Definition by Hopcroft+Ullman 1979---> In contemporary publications following Hopcroft and Ullman (1979), {{refn|Hopcroft and Ullman (1979),<ref name=Hopcroft_and_Ullman>{{cite book | last = [[John Hopcroft|Hopcroft]] | first = John E. | author2 = [[Jeffrey D. Ullman]] | title = [[Introduction to Automata Theory, Languages, and Computation]] | year = 1979 | publisher = Addison-Wesley | isbn = 0-201-02988-X}}</ref> Sect.14.3, p.389-390. This section is omitted in the 2nd edition 2003.}} an indexed grammar is formally defined a 5-tuple ''G'' = ⟨''N'',''T'',''F'',''P'',''S''⟩ where
* ''N'' is a set of variables or [[Nonterminal|nonterminal symbols]], * ''T'' is a set ("[[alphabet (formal languages)|alphabet]]") of terminal symbols, * ''F'' is a set of so-called ''index symbols'', or ''indices'', * ''S'' ∈ ''N'' is the ''[[start symbol (formal languages)|start symbol]]'', and * ''P'' is a finite set of ''[[Production (formal languages)|productions]]''.
In productions as well as in derivations of indexed grammars, a string ("stack") ''σ'' ∈ ''F''[[Kleene star|<sup>*</sup>]] of index symbols is attached to every nonterminal symbol ''A'' ∈ ''N'', denoted by ''A''[''σ''].<ref group=note>"[" and "]" are meta symbols to indicate the stack.</ref> Terminal symbols may not be followed by index stacks. For an index stack ''σ'' ∈ ''F''<sup>*</sup> and a string ''α'' ∈ (''N'' ∪ ''T'')<sup>*</sup> of nonterminal and terminal symbols, ''α''[''σ''] denotes the result of attaching [''σ''] to every nonterminal in ''α''; for example if ''α'' equals {{math|''a'' ''B'' ''C'' ''d'' ''E''}} with ''a'',''d'' ∈ ''T'' terminal, and {{math|''B'',''C'',''E'' ∈ ''N''}} nonterminal symbols, then ''α''[''σ''] denotes {{math|''a'' ''B''[''σ''] ''C''[''σ''] ''d'' ''E''[''σ''].}} Using this notation, each production in ''P'' has to be of the form
# ''A''[σ] → α[σ], # ''A''[σ] → ''B''[''f''σ], or # ''A''[''f''σ] → α[σ],
where ''A'', ''B'' ∈ ''N'' are nonterminal symbols, ''f'' ∈ ''F'' is an index, ''σ'' ∈ ''F''<sup>*</sup> is a string of index symbols, and ''α'' ∈ (''N'' ∪ ''T'')<sup>*</sup> is a string of nonterminal and terminal symbols. Some authors write ".." instead of "''σ''" for the index stack in production rules; the rule of type 1, 2, and 3 then reads {{math|''A''[..]→''α''[..],   ''A''[..]→''B''[''f''..]}}, and {{math|''A''[''f''..]→''α''[..]}}, respectively.
Derivations are similar to those in a [[context-free grammar#Rule application|context-free grammar]] except for the index stack attached to each nonterminal symbol. When a production like e.g. ''A''[''σ''] → ''B''[''σ'']''C''[''σ''] is applied, the index stack of ''A'' is copied to both ''B'' and ''C''. Moreover, a rule can push an index symbol onto the stack, or pop its "topmost" (i.e., leftmost) index symbol.
Formally, the relation ⇒ ("direct derivation") is defined on the set (''N''[''F''<sup>*</sup>]∪''T'')<sup>*</sup> of "sentential forms" as follows: #If ''A''[''σ''] → ''α''[''σ''] is a production of type 1, then β ''A''[''φ''] ''γ'' ⇒ ''β'' ''α''[''φ''] ''γ'', using the above definition. That is, the rule's left hand side's index stack ''φ'' is copied to each nonterminal of the right hand side. #If ''A''[''σ''] → ''B''[''fσ''] is a production of type 2, then ''β'' ''A''[''φ''] ''γ'' ⇒ ''β'' ''B''[''fφ''] ''γ''. That is, the right hand side's index stack is obtained from the left hand side's stack ''φ'' by pushing ''f'' onto it. #If ''A''[''fσ''] → ''α''[''σ''] is a production of type 3, then ''β'' ''A''[''fφ''] ''γ'' ⇒ ''β'' ''α''[''φ''] ''γ'', using again the definition of ''α''[''σ'']. That is, the first index ''f'' is popped from the left hand side's stack, which is then distributed to each nonterminal of the right hand side.
As usual, the derivation relation {{overset|[[reflexive transitive closure|∗]]|⇒}} is defined as the [[reflexive transitive closure]] of direct derivation ⇒. The language ''L''(''G'') = { ''w'' ∈ ''T''<sup>*</sup>: ''S'' {{overset|∗|⇒}} ''w'' } is the set of all strings of terminal symbols derivable from the start symbol. <!---contents of former section "Description"---> <!---now contained in the informal description of the derivation relation and the note about meta symbols--->
===Original definition by Aho===
<!---former section "Definition"---> Historically, indexed grammar were introduced by [[Alfred Aho]] (1968)<ref name="aho1968">{{cite journal | last = [[Alfred Aho|Aho]] | first = Alfred | year = 1968 | title = Indexed grammars—an extension of context-free grammars | journal = [[Journal of the ACM]] | volume = 15 | issue = 4 | pages = 647–671 | url = http://portal.acm.org/ft_gateway.cfm?id=321488&type=pdf&coll=GUIDE&dl=GUIDE,&CFID=17841194&CFTOKEN=70113868 | doi = 10.1145/321479.321488 }}</ref> using a different formalism. Aho defined an indexed grammar to be a 5-tuple (''N'',''T'',''F'',''P'',''S'') where # ''N'' is a finite [[alphabet]] of variables or [[Nonterminal|nonterminal symbols]] # ''T'' is a finite alphabet of terminal symbols # ''F'' ⊆ [[power set|2]]<sup>''N'' × (''N'' ∪ ''T'')[[Kleene star|<sup>*</sup>]]</sup> is the finite set of so-called ''flags'' (each flag is itself a set of so-called ''index productions'') # ''P'' ⊆ ''N'' × (''NF''<sup>*</sup> ∪ ''T'')<sup>*</sup> is the finite set of ''[[Production (computer science)|productions]]'' # ''S'' ∈ ''N'' is the ''start symbol''
Direct derivations were as follows:
* A production ''p'' = (''A'' → ''X''<sub>1</sub>''η''<sub>1</sub>…''X''<sub>''k''</sub>''η''<sub>''k''</sub>) from ''P'' matches a nonterminal ''A'' ∈ ''N'' followed by its (possibly empty) string of flags ''ζ'' ∈ ''F''<sup>*</sup>. In context, ''γ'' ''Aζ'' ''δ'', via ''p'', derives to ''γ'' ''X''<sub>1</sub>''θ''<sub>1</sub>…''X''<sub>''k''</sub>''θ''<sub>''k''</sub> ''δ'', where ''θ''<sub>''i''</sub> = ''η''<sub>''i''</sub>''ζ'' if ''X''<sub>''i''</sub> was a nonterminal and the empty word otherwise. The old flags of ''A'' are therefore ''copied'' to each new nonterminal produced by ''p''. Each such production can be simulated by appropriate productions of type 1 and 2 in the Hopcroft/Ullman formalism. * An index production ''p'' = (''A'' → ''X''<sub>1</sub>…''X''<sub>''k''</sub>) ∈ ''f'' matches ''Afζ'' (the flag ''f'' it comes from must match the first symbol following the nonterminal ''A'') and copies the remaining index string ''ζ'' to each new nonterminal: ''γ'' ''Afζ'' ''δ'' derives to ''γ'' ''X''<sub>1</sub>''θ''<sub>1</sub>…''X''<sub>''k''</sub>''θ''<sub>''k''</sub> ''δ'', where ''θ''<sub>''i''</sub> is the empty word when ''X''<sub>''i''</sub> is a terminal and ''ζ'' when it is a nonterminal. Each such production corresponds to a production of type 3 in the Hopcroft/Ullman formalism.
This formalism is e.g. used by Hayashi (1973, p. 65-66).<ref name="Hayashi.1973">{{cite journal| author=T. Hayashi| title=On Derivation Trees of Indexed Grammars - An Extension of the ''uvxyz'' Theorem| journal=Publication of the Research Institute for Mathematical Sciences| year=1973| volume=9| number=1| pages=61–92| institution=Research Institute for Mathematical Sciences| url=http://www.ems-ph.org/journals/show_pdf.php?issn=0034-5318&vol=9&iss=1&rank=3| doi=10.2977/prims/1195192738}}</ref>
==Examples==
<!---former section "Example"---> In practice, stacks of indices can count and remember what rules were applied and in which order. For example, indexed grammars can describe the context-sensitive language of word triples { ''www'' : ''w'' ∈ {''a'',''b''}<sup>*</sup> }:
:{| |- | ''S''[''σ''] || → || ''S''[''fσ''] | ''T''[''fσ''] || → || ''a'' ''T''[''σ''] |- | ''S''[''σ''] || → || ''S''[''gσ''] | ''T''[''gσ''] || → || ''b'' ''T''[''σ''] |- | ''S''[''σ''] || → || ''T''[''σ''] ''T''[''σ''] ''T''[''σ'']       | ''T''[] || → || ''ε'' |}
A derivation of ''{{not a typo|abbabbabb}}'' is then
:{{math|size=100%|''S''[]}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''S''[''g'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''S''[''gg'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''S''[''fgg'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''T''[''fgg''] ''T''[''fgg''] ''T''[''fgg'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''a'' ''T''[''gg''] ''T''[''fgg''] ''T''[''fgg'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''ab'' ''T''[''g''] ''T''[''fgg''] ''T''[''fgg'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''abb'' ''T''[] ''T''[''fgg''] ''T''[''fgg'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''abb'' ''T''[''fgg''] ''T''[''fgg'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|...}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''abb'' ''abb'' ''T''[''fgg'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|...}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''abb'' ''abb'' ''abb''}}.
<!---supplemented from talk page # Example by Hopcroft+Ullman 1979---> As another example, the grammar ''G'' = ⟨ {''S'',''T'',''A'',''B'',''C''}, {''a'',''b'',''c''}, {''f'',''g''}, ''P'', ''S'' ⟩ produces the language { ''a''<sup>''n''</sup>''b''<sup>''n''</sup>''c''<sup>''n''</sup>: ''n'' ≥ 1 }, where the production set ''P'' consists of :{| |- | ''S''[''σ''] → ''T''[''gσ''] || ''A''[''fσ''] → ''a'' ''A''[''σ''] || ''A''[''gσ''] → ''a'' |- | ''T''[''σ''] → ''T''[''fσ''] || ''B''[''fσ''] → ''b'' ''B''[''σ''] || ''B''[''gσ''] → ''b'' |- | ''T''[''σ''] → ''A''[''σ''] ''B''[''σ''] ''C''[''σ'']       || ''C''[''fσ''] → ''c'' ''C''[''σ'']       || ''C''[''gσ''] → ''c'' |} An example derivation is :{{math|size=100%|''S''[]}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''T''[''g'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''T''[''fg'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''A''[''fg''] ''B''[''fg''] ''C''[''fg'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''aA''[''g''] ''B''[''fg''] ''C''[''fg'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''aA''[''g''] ''bB''[''g''] ''C''[''fg'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''aA''[''g''] ''bB''[''g''] ''cC''[''g'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''aa'' ''bB''[''g''] ''cC''[''g'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''aa'' ''bb'' ''cC''[''g'']}} ⇒ {{math|size=100%|''aa'' ''bb'' ''cc''}}.
Both example languages are [[Pumping lemma for context-free languages#Usage of the lemma|known]] to be not context-free.
==Properties==
<!---former contents of section "Description" (added 3 Feb 2014)---> [[John Hopcroft|Hopcroft]] and [[Jeffrey Ullman|Ullman]] tend to consider indexed languages as a "natural" class, since they are generated by several formalisms other than indexed grammars, viz.{{refn|Hopcroft and Ullman (1979),<ref name=Hopcroft_and_Ullman/> Bibliographic notes, p.394-395}} * [[Alfred Aho|Aho]]'s one-way [[nested stack automata]]<ref>{{cite journal| author=Alfred Aho| title=Nested Stack Automata| journal=Journal of the ACM| year=1969| volume=16| number=3| pages=383–406| doi=10.1145/321526.321529}}</ref> * [[Michael J. Fischer|Fischer]]'s macro grammars<ref>{{cite book| author=Michael J. Fischer| chapter=Grammars with Macro-Like Productions| title=Proc. 9th Ann. IEEE Symp. on Switching and Automata Theory (SWAT)| year=1968| pages=131–142}}</ref> * [[Sheila Greibach|Greibach]]'s automata with stacks of stacks<ref>{{cite journal| author=Sheila A. Greibach| title=Full AFL's and Nested Iterated Substitution| journal=Information and Control| year=1970| volume=16| number=1| pages=7–35| url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0019995870800390/pdf?md5=c960de360ba704b0f5403b6f95dd19f8&pid=1-s2.0-S0019995870800390-main.pdf| doi=10.1016/s0019-9958(70)80039-0}}</ref> * [[Tom Maibaum|Maibaum]]'s algebraic characterization<ref>{{cite journal| author=T.S.E. Maibaum| title=A Generalized Approach to Formal Languages| journal=Journal of Computer and System Sciences| year=1974| volume=8| number=3| pages=409–439| url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0022000074800310/pdf?md5=0c71b0ce688b0d4ca81a181089b02af9&pid=1-s2.0-S0022000074800310-main.pdf| doi=10.1016/s0022-0000(74)80031-0}}</ref>
Hayashi<ref name="Hayashi.1973"/> generalized the [[Pumping lemma for context-free languages|pumping lemma]] to indexed grammars. Conversely, Gilman<ref>{{cite journal| author=Robert H. Gilman| title=A Shrinking Lemma for Indexed Languages| journal=Theoretical Computer Science| year=1996| volume=163| pages=277–281| url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0304397596002447/pdf?md5=33e62c7398fd8c6fb98f6759b154dcbd&pid=1-s2.0-0304397596002447-main.pdf| doi=10.1016/0304-3975(96)00244-7}}</ref><ref>{{cite arxiv| author=Robert H. Gilman| title=A Shrinking Lemma for Indexed Languages|date=Sep 1995| arxiv=math/9509205}}</ref> gives a "shrinking lemma" for indexed languages.
==Linear indexed grammars==
[[Gerald Gazdar]] has defined a second class, the '''linear indexed grammars''' ('''LIG'''),{{refn|According to Staudacher (1993, p.361 left, Sect.2.2),<ref name="staudacher1993"/> the name "linear indexed grammars" wasn't used in Gazdar's 1988 paper, but appeared later, e.g. in Weir and Joshi (1988).<ref>{{cite book|author1=David J. Weir |author2=Aravind K. Joshi | chapter=Combinatory Categorial Grammars: Generative Power and Relationship to Linear Context-Free Rewriting Systems| title=Proc. 26th Meeting Assoc. Comput. Ling.| year=1988| pages=278–285| url=http://acl.ldc.upenn.edu/P/P88/P88-1034.pdf?origin=publication_detail}}</ref>}} by requiring that at most one nonterminal in each production be specified as receiving the stack,<ref group=note>all other nonterminals receive an empty stack</ref> whereas in an ordinary indexed grammar, all nonterminals receive copies of the stack. Formally, a linear indexed grammar is defined similar to an ordinary indexed grammar, but the production's form requirements are modified to:
# ''A''[''σ''] → ''α''[] ''B''[''σ''] ''β''[], # ''A''[''σ''] → ''α''[] ''B''[''fσ''] ''β''[], # ''A''[''fσ''] → ''α''[] ''B''[''σ''] ''β''[],
where ''A'', ''B'', ''f'', ''σ'', ''α'' are used as [[#Modern definition by Hopcroft and Ullman|above]], and ''β'' ∈ (''N'' ∪ ''T'')<sup>*</sup> is a string of nonterminal and terminal symbols like ''α''.<ref group=note name="Gazdars def">In order to generate any string at all, some productions must be admitted having no nonterminal symbol on their right hand side. However, Gazdar didn't discuss this issue.</ref> Also, the direct derivation relation ⇒ is defined similar to above. This new class of grammars defines a strictly smaller class of languages,<ref name="gazdar1998">{{cite book | chapter=Applicability of Indexed Grammars to Natural Languages | year=1988 | last=Gazdar | first=Gerald | title=Natural Language Parsing and Linguistic Theories | editor=U. Reyle and C. Rohrer | pages=69–94 | publisher=D. Reidel Publishing Company | isbn=1-55608-055-7 | series=Studies in linguistics and philosophy |volume=35}}</ref> which belongs to the [[mildly context-sensitive language|mildly context-sensitive]] classes.
The language { ''www'' : ''w'' ∈ {''a'',''b''}<sup>*</sup> } is generable by an indexed grammar, but not by a linear indexed grammar, while both { ''ww'' : ''w'' ∈ {''a'',''b''}<sup>*</sup> } and { ''a''<sup>''n''</sup> ''b''<sup>''n''</sup> ''c''<sup>''n''</sup> : n ≥ 1 } are generable by a linear indexed grammar.
If both the original and the modified production rules are admitted, the language class remains the indexed languages.<ref>Gazdar (1988), Appendix, p.89</ref>
===Example===
Letting σ denote an arbitrary collection of stack symbols, we can define a grammar for the language ''L'' = {''a''<sup>''n''</sup> ''b''<sup>''n''</sup> ''c''<sup>''n''</sup> | ''n'' ≥ 1 }{{refn|Cf. the properly indexed grammar for the same language given [[#Examples|above]]. The last rule, viz. ''T''[]→ε, of the linear indexed grammar doesn't conform to Gazdar's definition in a strict sense, cf. <ref group=note name="Gazdars def"/>|group=note}} as
:{| |- | ''S''[''σ''] || → || ''a S''[''fσ''] ''c'' |- | ''S''[''σ''] || → || ''T''[''σ''] |- | ''T''[''fσ''] || → || ''T''[''σ''] ''b'' |- | ''T''[] || → || ''ε'' |}
To derive the string ''abc'' we have the steps ''S''[] ⇒ ''aS''[''f'']''c'' ⇒ ''aT''[''f'']''c'' ⇒ ''aT''[]''bc'' ⇒ ''abc''.
Similarly: ''S''[] ⇒ ''aS''[''f'']''c'' ⇒ ''aaS''[''ff'']''cc'' ⇒ ''aaT''[''ff'']''cc'' ⇒ ''aaT''[''f'']''bcc'' ⇒ ''aaT''[]''bbcc'' ⇒ ''aabbcc''.
===Computational power===
The linearly indexed languages are a subset of the indexed languages, and thus all LIGs can be recoded as IGs, making the LIGs strictly less powerful than the IGs. A conversion from a LIG to an IG is relatively simple.<ref>Gazdar 1988, Appendix, p.89-91</ref> LIG rules in general look approximately like <math>X[\sigma] \to \alpha Y[\sigma] \beta</math>, modulo the push/pop part of a rewrite rule. The symbols <math>\alpha</math> and <math>\beta</math> represent strings of terminal and/or non-terminal symbols, and any non-terminal symbol in either must have an empty stack, by the definition of a LIG. This is, of course, counter to how IGs are defined: in an IG, the non-terminals whose stacks are not being pushed to or popped from must have exactly the same stack as the rewritten non-terminal. Thus, somehow, we need to have non-terminals in <math>\alpha</math> and <math>\beta</math> which, despite having non-empty stacks, behave as if they had empty stacks.
Let's consider the rule <math>X[\sigma] \to Y[] Z[\sigma f]</math> as an example case. In converting this to an IG, the replacement for <math>Y[]</math> must be some <math>Y^{\prime}[\sigma]</math> that behaves exactly like <math>Y[]</math> regardless of what <math>\sigma</math> is. To achieve this, we can simply have a pair of rules that takes any <math>Y^{\prime}[\sigma]</math> where <math>\sigma</math> is not empty, and pops symbols from the stack. Then, when the stack is empty, it can be rewritten as <math>Y[]</math>.
: <math>Y^{\prime}[\sigma f] \to Y^{\prime}[\sigma]</math>
: <math>Y^{\prime}[] \to Y[]</math> We can apply this in general to derive an IG from an LIG. So for example if the LIG for the language <math>\{a^n b^n c^n d^m | n \geq 1, m \geq 1\}</math> is as follows:
: <math>S[\sigma] \to T[\sigma]V[]</math>
: <math>V[] \to d ~|~ dV[]</math>
: <math>T[\sigma] \to aT[\sigma f]c ~|~ U[\sigma]</math>
: <math>U[\sigma f] \to bU[\sigma]</math>
: <math>U[] \to \epsilon</math> The sentential rule here is not an IG rule, but using the above conversion algorithm, we can define new rules for <math>V^{\prime}</math>, changing the grammar to:
: <math>S[\sigma] \to T[\sigma]V^{\prime}[\sigma]</math>
: <math>V^{\prime}[\sigma f] \to V^{\prime}[\sigma]</math>
: <math>V^{\prime}[] \to V[]</math>
: <math>V[] \to d ~|~ dV[]</math>
: <math>T[\sigma] \to aT[\sigma f]c ~|~ U[\sigma]</math>
: <math>U[\sigma f] \to bU[\sigma]</math>
: <math>U[] \to \epsilon</math> Each rule now fits the definition of an IG, in which all the non-terminals in the right hand side of a rewrite rule receive a copy of the rewritten symbol's stack. The indexed grammars are therefore able to describe all the languages that linearly indexed grammars can describe.
===Relation to other formalism===
Vijay-Shanker and Weir (1994)<ref name="vijayshankarAndWeir1995">{{cite journal |author=Vijay-Shanker, K. |author2=Weir, David J. 1994. |title=The Equivalence of Four Extensions of Context-Free Grammars |journal=Mathematical Systems Theory |volume=27 |issue=6 |pages=511–546 |url=http://citeseer.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.52.4044&rep=rep1&type=pdf |doi=10.1007/bf01191624}}</ref> demonstrates that Linear Indexed Grammars, [[Combinatory categorial grammar|Combinatory Categorial Grammars]], [[Tree-adjoining grammar|Tree-adjoining Grammars]], and [[Head grammar|Head Grammars]] all define the same class of string languages. Their formal definition of linear indexed grammars<ref>p.517-518</ref> differs from the [[#Linear indexed grammars|above]].{{clarify|date=August 2014}}
LIGs (and their [[Equivalence (formal languages)|weakly equivalents]]) are strictly less expressive (meaning they generate a proper subset) than the languages generated by another family of weakly equivalent formalism, which include: [[LCFRS]], [[MCTAG]], [[MCFG]] and [[minimalist grammar]]s (MGs). The latter family can (also) be parsed in [[polynomial time]].<ref name="BenthemMeulen2010">{{cite book|author1=Johan F.A.K. van Benthem|author2=Alice ter Meulen|title=Handbook of Logic and Language|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K7yJLmZCbFUC&pg=PA404|year=2010|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=978-0-444-53727-0|page=404|edition=2nd}}</ref>
==Distributed index grammars== Another form of indexed grammars, introduced by Staudacher (1993),<ref name="staudacher1993">{{citation |author=Staudacher, Peter |year=1993 |title=New frontiers beyond context-freeness: DI-grammars (DIGs) and DI-automata. |booktitle=Sixth Conference of the European Chapter of the Association for Computational Linguistics (EACL '93) |url=http://acl.ldc.upenn.edu/E/E93/E93-1042.pdf |pages=358–367 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060719224223/http://acl.ldc.upenn.edu/E/E93/E93-1042.pdf |archivedate=2006-07-19 |df= }}</ref> is the class of Distributed Index grammars (DIGs). What distinguishes DIGs from Aho's Indexed Grammars is the propagation of indexes. Unlike Aho's IGs, which distribute the whole symbol stack to all non-terminals during a rewrite operation, DIGs divide the stack into substacks and distributes the substacks to selected non-terminals.
The general rule schema for a binarily distributing rule of DIG is the form
: ''X''[''f''<sub>1</sub>...''f''<sub>''i''</sub>''f''<sub>''i''+1</sub>...''f''<sub>''n''</sub>] → ''α'' ''Y''[f<sub>1</sub>...''f''<sub>''i''</sub>] ''β'' ''Z''[''f''<sub>''i''+1</sub>...''f''<sub>''n''</sub>] γ Where α, β, and γ are arbitrary terminal strings. For a ternarily distributing string:
: ''X''[''f''<sub>1</sub>...''f''<sub>''i''</sub>''f''<sub>''i''+1</sub>...''f''<sub>''j''</sub>''f''<sub>''j''+1</sub>...''f''<sub>''n''</sub>] → ''α'' ''Y''[f<sub>1</sub>...''f''<sub>''i''</sub>] ''β'' ''Z''[''f''<sub>''i''+1</sub>...''f''<sub>''j''</sub>] ''γ'' ''W''[''f''<sub>''j''+1</sub>...''f''<sub>''n''</sub>] ''η'' And so forth for higher numbers of non-terminals in the right hand side of the rewrite rule. In general, if there are ''m'' non-terminals in the right hand side of a rewrite rule, the stack is partitioned ''m'' ways and distributed amongst the new non-terminals. Notice that there is a special case where a partition is empty, which effectively makes the rule a LIG rule. The Distributed Index languages are therefore a superset of the Linearly Indexed languages.

{{Cleanup|date=May 2010}} [[Image:Eliezer Ben-Yehuda at his desk in Jerusalem - c1912.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Eliezer Ben-Yehuda]], father of modern Hebrew]] {{see also|Hebrew literature}} '''Israeli literature''' is [[literature]] written in the [[State of Israel]] by [[Israelis]]. Most works classed as Israeli literature are written in the [[Hebrew language]], although some Israeli authors write in [[Yiddish]], [[English language|English]], [[Arabic language|Arabic]] and [[Russian language|Russian]]. ==History== ===Hebrew writers=== The foundations of modern Israel writing were laid by a group of literary pioneers from the [[Second Aliyah]] including [[Shmuel Yosef Agnon]], the only Nobel Prize winner for literature in Hebrew and the only one for Israeli literature, [[Moshe Smilansky]], [[Yosef Haim Brenner]], [[David Shimoni]], and [[Jacob Fichman]]. Until World War I, Hebrew literature was centered in Eastern Europe. After the war and the [[Russian Revolution (1917)|Russian Revolution]] many Hebrew writers found their way to Palestine, so that at the time Palestinian writing was essentially a continuation of the European tradition. In 1921, 70 writers met in Tel Aviv and founded the Hebrew Writers' Association. About this time the first literary periodicals made their appearance—''Ha-Adamah'', edited by Brenner, and ''Ma'abarot'', edited by Fichman. The 1920 and 1930s witnessed the emergence of Palestine as the dominant center of Hebrew literary activity. Many of the pioneers of Hebrew literature were Zionists, and eventually made their way to Palestine. The great figures of the early part of the century—[[Bialik]], [[Ahad Ha-Am]], [[Shaul Tchernichovsky|Tchernichovsky]]—all spent their last years in Tel Aviv, and although this was not the period of their greatest creativity, they exerted a great influence on younger Hebrew writers.<ref>http://www.myjewishlearning.com/culture/literature/FinalEdit_Literature_TO_HebrewLit.html</ref>
Among the earliest modern Hebrew writers was a small minority of writers who were born in Palestine. This cadre includes [[Yitzhaq Shami]] <!-- ([[:he:יצחק שמי]])--> and [[Yehuda Burla]] <!-- ([[:he:יהודה בורלא]])-->, Sepharadi Jews whose families migrated to Palestine in the 19th and 18th centuries, respectively. The writing of this group stands out for its authentic depiction of the Arab and Jewish population of Palestine, told from the vantage point of those who grew up in its midst.
The most important writers of the first generation, S.Y. Agnon and [[Haim Hazaz]], were deeply rooted in their European background, and served as links between the classical writers of the early decades of the [[Revival of the Hebrew language|Hebrew revival]] and the Hebrew writers in Palestine during the following generations.
For the next generation of writers, the center of focus was Palestine, even when they were writing about other parts of the world. Their framework was the period of [[aliyah]] and, very often, life in the [[kibbutz]]. Among the outstanding names are [[Uri Zvi Greenberg]] and [[Avraham Shlonsky]], who found in Palestine the antidote to the rootlessness of the Diaspora.
The third generation of writers emerged around the time of the [[Israeli war of independence]]. Its key figures ([[S. Yizhar]], [[Moshe Shamir]], [[Hanoch Bartov]], [[Haim Gouri]], [[Benjamin Tammuz]], [[Aharon Megged]]) were all [[Sabra (person)|sabras]] or had been brought to the country at an early age. Strong influences now came in from other countries, especially Western. A group called the "[[Canaanites (movement)|Canaanites]]" even sought to deny the connection between Israelis and Jews elsewhere. But after 1948, a feeling of emptiness and of searching for new values was leading to experiments in exploring the Jewish past.
The subsequent generation of the 1960s ([[A. B. Yehoshua]], [[Amos Oz]], [[Natan Yonatan]], [[Yoram Kaniuk]], [[Yaakov Shabtai]]) has endeavoured to place [[Israeli culture]] within a world context and stresses not so much the unique aspects of Jewish life and Israel as the universal. This school of writers often identifies itself with the protest literature of other countries.
The following generation, writers who were born in the 1960s and 1970s and made their debut in the 1980s and 1990s, examined the basic questions of Jewish-Israeli existence by exposing the collective tensions in individual characters and fates.<ref>[[Encyclopaedia Judaica]], vol. 9, p. 1001-1002</ref>
===Yiddish writers=== Apart from Hebrew writers, there is considerable creative productivity in Israel in other languages, notably in Yiddish. Before World War II, Warsaw, Moscow, and New York were the main centers of Yiddish activity. In Palestine there was still a certain hostility to the Yiddish language, which was felt as a challenge to the Hebrew revival. However, with World War II the whole picture changed. The European centers were liquidated by Hitler and Stalin, and the New York center declined. Immigration brought many of the leading Yiddish writers to Israel. Here the internal attitude relaxed and became friendly, in view of the Holocaust in Europe, on the one hand, and the secure position attained by Hebrew, on the other.
Yiddish writing in Israel can be marked by generations, similar to those in Hebrew literature. The first consisted of writers such as [[David Pinski]] and [[Sholem Asch]], who passed their last years in Israel. The second generation, led by [[Abraham Sutzkever]], started its career in Eastern Europe but continued in Israel. The third generation was centered on "Young Israel", a [[Modernism|modernist]] group of poets and prose writers, most of whom are kibbutz members, whose work has been influenced by the avant-garde schools of [[English literature|English]] and [[French literature|French writing]].
Yiddish writing in Israel is concentrated on the European Holocaust (the leading writer on this is [[Ka-Tzetnik]]), and life among new immigrants. Yiddish authors in Israel are organized in a Yiddish authors' association.<ref>[[Encyclopaedia Judaica]], vol. 9, p. 1003</ref>
===Arabic writers=== The presence of Arabic-language literature in [[Israelis|Israeli]] society can be initially attributed to [[Emile Habibi]], an Israeli-Palestinian writer and a communist politician. In 1992, he was awarded the [[Israel Prize]] for Arabic literature. A fervent communist, Habibi helped created the [[Maki (historical political party)|Israeli Communist Party]] and established ''Al-Ittihad'', a communist daily [[Arabic language]] newspaper published in [[Haifa]]. Habibi's works, while often a critique of [[Israelis|Israeli]] society, are nevertheless part of [[Israeli culture]].
==Publication of books in Israel== By law, the [[Jewish National and University Library]] of the [[Hebrew University of Jerusalem]] receives two copies of each book published in Israel. In 2004 it reported that it received 6,436 new books. Most of them were published in Hebrew, and 89% those books published in Hebrew were original to the Hebrew language. Almost 8% of the 2004 crop were children's books and another 4% were textbooks. According to the type of publisher, the books were 55% commercial, 14% self-published, 10% governmental, 7% educational, and 14% published by other types of organizations. The orthodox and ultra-orthodox sector was responsible for 21% of the total titles.<ref>[http://www.hunews.huji.ac.il/articles.asp?cat=3&artID=455 Hebrew University of Jerusalem news] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080322204249/http://www.hunews.huji.ac.il/articles.asp?cat=3&artID=455 |date=2008-03-22 }}</ref> 2017 figures show that 17% of books were Torah-related, 16% were literature and 14% children's books.<ref>Tal Polon: [http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/246986 Israeli books: More Torah-related books than any other type] Arutz 7, 05/06/18.</ref>
